title: Re: .mod file creator
content:
So, MOD files are exactly the same thing as MIDIs, except that the sound samples are embedded in the file, instead of having it in a separate (patch)file that comes with the player.

I guess then you convert a MIDI to a MOD file, adding your favorite samples from MIDI patches, and get a "what you hear is what you will always hear" music file.

Do you understand? [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] It's just an idea to rid a poor game engine of some MIDI sampling problems under different platforms. Is it possible?[hr][img]http://img136.imageshack.us/img136/983/vegetableswk2.gif[/img]

title: Re: .mod file creator
content:
Not quite - saying a MOD file is like a MIDI with embedded instruments is just a simple way of explaining the major difference. MOD files have tons of "effects" for enhancing the music whereas MIDI effects don't go much beyond pitchbends and reverb.

On the other hand, MIDIs have unlimited "polyphony" (you can play pretty much an unlimited number of notes at the same time, although again you may not hear them all depending on the sound card/software you're using for playback.) MOD files have a set number of channels (usually between four and 32) and you can only play one note at a time per channel.

This can often mean converting a MIDI to a MOD may lose some notes, especially if it's a complex song. But at least after the conversion it will sound the same everywhere [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

I suppose my point is that converting from one format to another will never be perfect, music will almost always sound the best when listened to in its original format, seeing as it will often have been composed specially to take advantage of that format's features.

title: Re: .mod file creator
content:
You're also forgetting the difference in how timing is done: modules have strict table patterns where each row is a small time instance, where MIDIs... Well, I don't know how the timing there works, but it's easier to go off-beat with that. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

Then there's the special instrument editor in some module trackers, with which you can enhance the samples and how they are played, and even how they sound when released at a certain point.

I prefer modules much over MIDIs, mostly because of the compatibility with all sound cards and the freedom of what you can do. The latest OpenMPT slightly supports VSTi's too. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] ____________

title: Re: .mod file creator
content:
There's a format...what is it now? RMI I think (remember those *.rmi files that came with Win95 along with the sample .wav and .mid?) That format was a "RIFF MIDI" which meant you could embed other data (like SoundFonts) in the file. The Windows examples had icons embedded into the file too (as did those sample .wav sounds, since .wav files are also in RIFF format.)

So you could embed your SF in with the MIDI and distribute it as a single .rmi file - but it does seem to be a pretty nonstandard extension as I haven't exactly seen a lot of .rmi files around.
